New Records: Jos Buttler moved past former skipper Eoin Morgan as England's leading run-scorer in T20I cricket, with 2,468 runs.
Key Match Events: Jos Buttler scored 73 runs, hitting his first six with an audacious ramp shot to a Lockie Ferguson ball from outside off to fine leg.
Glenn Phillips' magnificent 62 off 36 balls kept New Zealand in the chase until the final four overs.
Sam Curran took a huge catch to dismiss the dangerous Jimmy Neesham.
Jos Buttler took a diving catch to dismiss Devon Conway for a 9-ball 3 off a leg-side Chris Woakes delivery.
Ben Stokes fell LBW to Ferguson for 8 in the penultimate ball of the innings.
Pre-Game Insights: When England woke up this morning to persistent rain and leaden skies, there must have been fears of another washout, which would have been almost terminal for their chances of progression.
Post-Match Reflections: The result means everything rests on the final round of matches in group one, with England second, behind New Zealand and ahead of Australia on net run rate.
Miscellaneous Highlights: The clouds spent themselves by mid-afternoon and the perfect playing conditions ended up drawing a healthy crowd of 22,547 fans to the Gabba, 4,000 more than Monday's match between Australia and Ireland.
Others: Sri Lanka kept their narrow hopes alive with a six-wicket victory over Afghanistan at the same venue.
Afghanistan are out of the tournament, but should they rally for a victory, or even a narrow defeat, coupled with an England victory the following day would spell the end of Australia's campaign.
